Hi all! Here is my proposal for GSoC 2021:<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1-23x5GpBEr3PAY6gvCIGV50sXqYj3VwzOugU65GZnqI/edit?usp=sharing|https://docs.google.com/document/d/1-23x5GpBEr3PAY6gvCIGV50sXqYj3VwzOugU65GZnqI/edit?usp=sharing> 

Any feedback are welcome. Many thanks!

elements.text: Hi all! Here is my proposal for GSoC 2021:
Any feedback are welcome. Many thanks!

text: Hey, nice proposal. Just wanted to ask, which software you used for nice graphics of code? Thanks

elements.text: Hey, nice proposal. Just wanted to ask, which software you used for nice graphics of code? Thanks

text:
I find the "Julian" odd.
I imagine that your application will be read by a person which has no domain knowledge, awareness of the Julia ecosystem etc...
I would put more details about Turing and what nested sampling is in the abstract. I skimmed your paper and it didn't jump out to me why the reader should care. (This might sound harsh but i would try to make it interesting and approachable for the reader.)

Furthermore i would motivate and explain probabalistic programming more. Maybe something like:
In the real world noisy variables interact in ways which can not be captured by describing distributions directly in mathematical language. Probabilistic programming expresses such processes as interacting variables via computer programs. A common technique to evaluate such programs is sampling.

Tell why Turing is awesome. Tell why nested sampling is mathematically beautiful/performant. Tell why this is a match made in heaven and how it will help other people and ecosystem at large or how it opens new avenues for research.

Anyway, that is my opinion but i never applied at GSOC so take it with a grain of salt.
